results.title: Quintet
results.brief_description: Members of the Victorian Wind Quintet, working in the Music Teachers Project at Bendigo, demostrate the flute, clarinet, oboe, french horn and bassoon. Introduced by Trevor Lunn.

results.title: Quintessence: five short films by Barry J. Hershey
results.creator_credit: Barry J Hersey and Waldon Woods Film
results.brief_description: This meditative exploration by filmmaker Barry J. Hersey presents life in a visual poetry. Themes of life, birth, death and spirit fill each piece. Form and substance are explored. Reality and art are questioned as we journey through the spiritually observant eyes of the filmmaker. Each piece reveals the different and crucial aspects of the human condition and the place or insignificance of a person on earth. The nature and contours of the landscape are seen through new eyes while the suggestive ocean offers deeper interpretations of the world around us. The filmmaker makes use of the effects that music has on the visual experience with dreamy and relaxing sounds unifying the meditative aspects of this style of filmmaking.

results.title: Quick rise
results.brief_description: Time lapse photography is used to speed up the action in a town and a twenty storey building goes from ground level to completion in hour minutes. Visual speed is enhanced by a lively Bach piece preformed on a Moog synthesiser.

results.title: Question of prejudice
results.brief_description: A study of the racist atitudes of some Australians toward migrant Australians, highligting the ‘wog’ syndrome. Investigtes the discrimination shown in the workforce towards groups such as the Lebanese, and its human effects such as the loss of self-esteem. Includes the views of Robert Cameron (White Australia Movement) and children.

results.title: Quest for flight
results.creator_credit: Robert Boucher, Alan P. Sloan and Avator Learning
results.brief_description: Traces the history of aviation from the 15th Century when Leonardo da Vinci realised that flight was not an idle dream, through to air travel today. Traces the history of human’s attempts to imitate the bird from Icarus’ feathered wings to the Supersonic Transport system, focusing on Leonardo Da Vinci, Santos, Dumont, the Wright Brothers, and the significant technological advances made during World War I and III that have led to increased availability today. Also depicts renewed interest in simple forms of flight.

results.title: Putting the atom to work
results.brief_description: Atomic power in medicine, food preservation, and generation of electric power, future uses, and the dangers of nuclear energy. Calder Hall and Chapel Cross nuclear power stations. Britain’s first nuclear power programme consists of a number of stations. In 1962 the first of these started operating at Berkeley. A simple account of applied nuclear fission in Britain, showing the operation of nuclear power stations and production of radioactive isotopes.

results.title: Protist ecology (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Discusses the vital role played by protists in the ecology of the planet Earth. Examines the commensal, parasitic, and mutualistic life styles practiced by a large number of protist species.

results.title: Planet earth: science in space
results.creator_credit: Louis de Rochemont Associates, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Traces the development of space research; explains the need for satellites, rockets and other space probes; demonstrates how such tools operate; shows how their findings are reported; and discusses what they have contributed to our knowledge of space and of the solar system. Includes actual scenes of the assembly of instruments, the launching of satellites, and of the operation of tracking stations and computing centres.

results.title: The Flatworms (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce J. Russell and Modern Learning Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Shows planarian’s moving and detecting food; the taking of food into the branched intestine through a muscular pharynx. One animal is shown regenerating new parts. The microscope reveals tapeworms in a catfish. A living scolex is shown clinging to the intestinal wall. Several proglottids are shown in detail.
